pred_diverse_ans: Carbon dioxide gas (CO2) and a hydrogen ion (H+) are produced when water-soluble carboxylic acids slightly ionize in water.
Carboxylic acids form carboxylate ions when ionized in water.
The result of slight ionization of water-soluble carboxylic acids in water is the formation of a weak acid-base solution.
When water-soluble carboxylic acids ionize slightly in water, they produce hydrogen ions (H+) and a conjugate base.
When water-soluble carboxylic acids undergo slight ionization in water, the products are carboxylic acid ions and a proton.
Carboxylic acids, when slightly ionized in water, generate carboxyl ions and hydrogen ions.
We are left with slightly ionized carboxylic acids in water.
